intro: Poa pratensis var. vera, commonly known as meadow grass, is a variant of the bluegrass species native to temperate regions. It is characterized by its fine, tufted blades and dense growth habit, making it a common component of meadows and pastures. The plant typically grows to a height of 15–30 cm and has a fibrous root system that helps stabilize soil. It prefers well-drained soils and full to partial sunlight, often thriving in moist environments. Its ornamental value and use in turfgrass make it a significant species in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
